title: Automating Venture Capital: Founder assessment using LLM-powered segmentation, feature engineering and automated labeling techniques
abstract: This study explores the application of large language models (LLMs) in venture capital (VC) decision-making, focusing on predicting startup success based on founder characteristics. We utilize LLM prompting techniques, like chain-of-thought, to generate features from limited data, then extract insights through statistics and machine learning. Our results reveal potential relationships between certain founder characteristics and success, as well as demonstrate the effectiveness of these characteristics in prediction. This framework for integrating ML techniques and LLMs has vast potential for improving startup success prediction, with important implications for VC firms seeking to optimize their investment strategies.

sections.title: 1 Introduction
sections.content:
For venture capital (VC) firms, identifying early-stage startups with high potential for success is essential a difficult task given the countless variables at play. However, as tools like machine learning (ML) evolve, they present key opportunities to supplement VC funds' analyses and improve their investment strategies. Increasingly popular large language models (LLMs) can also support this process by quickly extracting insights from data that is otherwise difficult to parse.
This paper aims to introduce potential pathways for using ML and LLMs to predict the success of new startup founders. We leverage LLMs to propose and apply new features based on limited founder data that reflects the information available when a VC firm considers funding a company. We then use these features to gain insights and make predictions about startup success, demonstrating the vast potential for LLMs in this space.

sections.title: 2.1 Dataset
sections.content:
The original dataset comprised two CSV files respectively containing information about 1022 successful and 2694 unsuccessful startup founders. These founders are based in the United States and founded companies in 2010 or later. For the purpose of this paper, "success" means that the founder's company had an initial public offering with a valuation over $500M, was acquired for over $500M, or raised over $500M and is still operating.
The features of interest in the raw data were linkedin_json (all information from a founder's LinkedIn profile formatted in JSON) and org_name (the name of the founder's company). The use of these variables is described further in the following sections.
To prepare for the prediction of founder success, we combined the two original CSV files into one pandas dataframe and created a boolean flag column called success to distinguish successful and unsuccessful founders. sections.title: 2.2 Feature engineering
sections.content: Engineering features from the raw data involved several steps, including parsing the data through code and using an LLM, specifically OpenAI's GPT-40, to extract key information.

sections.title: 2.2.1 Processing education data
sections.content: Initially, more traditional techniques were used to extract educational information about each founder from their LinkedIn data. First, we parsed the LinkedIn data to determine each degree that a founder received and used this information to encode a variable, highest_edu, indicating the highest degree received by the founder. Each education level was mapped to an integer, as shown in Table 1.

sections.title: 2.2.2 Founder summaries
sections.content: The rest of the feature engineering process involved significant use of LLMs and prompting techniques, starting with the generation of summaries about each founder. Given a founder's LinkedIn data and latest company name, the LLM was prompted to provide a detailed summary of the founder including their education, location, skills, and employment history. The prompt emphasized that the model should focus on the time before the founder started their company, as this is the only information that would be available if a venture capitalist was assessing a new founder in a real-life situation.

sections.title: Generating levels
sections.content:
Previous research has segmented startup founders into five different categories, from L1 to L5, describing founders' level of experience and achievement in areas related to startup success. To provide more detailed insights, we used an unsupervised LLM-based method to increase the degree of segmentation to ten levels. The LLM was fed fifty founder summaries (generated in the previous section) and asked to propose a list of ten levels building upon the existing list of five. See the appendix for the specific prompt used to propose the ten levels.
We then refined the descriptions of the ten levels to improve specificity and the LLM's ability to produce correct outputs. The levels are as follows:
• Level 10 (L10): Serial entrepreneurs who have successfully founded and exited multiple companies, each with significant funding and valuation, typically above 100M+, and are consistently successful in scaling companies to IPO or large exits.
• Level 9 (L9): Entrepreneurs who have previously led unicorn (valuation > $1B) startups, before founding their current company.
• Level 8 (L8): Founders known for groundbreaking innovation, who have significantly disrupted or created new markets. Often recognized as thought leaders within the tech industry.
• Level 7 (L7): Founders who have previously scaled startups, securing substantial funding (50M-100M) and paving the way for potential IPO or major exit.
• Level 6 (L6): Founders who have had medium to large-sized exits and may have held key executive roles in notable tech companies.
• Level 5 (L5): Founders whose previous companies have secured substantial funding (100M+) with pending IPOs.
• Level 4 (L4): Founders with successful small to medium-sized exits or significant roles at notable technology companies.
• Level 3 (L3): Individuals with 10-15 years of technical and management expertise, including significant roles at high-growth tech companies or unicorn startups. May include academia with a PhD in relevant fields.
• Level 2 (L2): Founders with a few years of startup experience prior to founding their company, possibly graduates of well-known accelerator programs.
• Level 1 (L1): Founders who are relatively new to the tech industry, potentially with negligible experience but demonstrating high potential.

sections.title: Categorizing founders by level
sections.content:
After finalizing these levels, we implemented prompt chaining, feeding the previously generated founder summaries into an LLM so that it could categorize each founder as one of these levels. Then, level-based success rates were calculated by determining the number of founders within each level that were deemed to be successful.
This process utilized chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting to build on the few-shot technique. Few-shot CoT involves providing an example of the input, output, and reasoning that the LLM should follow to produce that output.

sections.title: Generating personas
sections.content:
The process of persona segmentation mimics that of level segmentation. Prior research has worked with ten personas describing key characteristics of founders beyond the information provided by level segmentation. Using a very similar unsupervised method to the previous section, we prompted the LLM to suggest a list of twenty personas based on the existing categories and fifty founder summaries.
After adjusting the wording for improved results, the final personas are as follows:
(A) Successful serial entrepreneur who built a public company.
(B) Successful serial entrepreneur who had a company with exit over $100M.
(C) Fresh graduate entrepreneur who founded a company immediately or within a year after university.
(D) First-time entrepreneur who founded a company within 3-5 years of finishing university.
(E) Founder holds a PhD degree or is/was a researcher, or is/was a professor at a university.
(F) First-time non-tech entrepreneur with 10+ years of experience in non-tech industries.
(G) Tech executive at tech company/companies for over 10 years.
(H) Engineer/executive at a unicorn company.
(I) Founder who has a background as an engineer or product manager at a tech firm.
(J) Founder with an MBA.
(K) Founder who has lived or worked in multiple countries.
(L) Serial entrepreneur with at least two companies started before.
(M) Founder who came from a corporate background but with less than 10 years of total experience.
(N) Founder with a background in finance, accounting, or economics.
(O) Founder who pivoted career paths from arts/humanities to tech entrepreneurship.
(P) Founder with experience in nonprofit organizations or social entrepreneurship.
(Q) Founder who has received notable awards or recognition in their industry (e.g., Forbes 30 under 30).
(R) Founder with a military service background.
(S) Female founder with notable achievements in male-dominated industries.
(T) Any others that are not in the above categories.
It is important to acknowledge that the use of unsupervised Large Language Model (LLM) prompting techniques may result in the generation of biased personas, such as (R). For the purposes of this research, we have elected to present the outputs of the unsupervised technique. This transparency aims to provide valuable insights that can inform the development of our future AI modeling techniques with a focus on ethical guardrails in our prompting constructs.

sections.title: Categorizing founders by persona
sections.content:
Once again, we implemented prompt chaining and few-shot CoT prompting to generate persona labels for each founder in the dataset. See the appendix for the full prompt.
In contrast to the level segmentation, founders could be assigned multiple personas. This variable was thus recorded in the data as several boolean columns corresponding to each possible persona. An analysis of success rates by persona followed.

sections.title: Generating boolean flags
sections.content:
To capture further information about startup founders, we added 23 boolean variables to the dataset. These variables were determined through an initial brainstorm and subsequent LLM prompting similar to previous prompting work.
The 23 boolean flags are as follows:
• is_firsttime_founder: 1 if the founder has created only one company. O if the founder has created more than one company.
• is_researcher: 1 if the founder worked as a researcher before starting their company. O otherwise.
• is_phd: 1 if the founder received a PhD or similar doctorate degree before starting their company. 0 otherwise.
• is_scholarship: 1 if the founder received a notable scholarship at some point before starting their company (for example, as a Fulbright Scholar). O otherwise.
• is_young_grad: 1 if the founder created their company within a year of finishing university. 0 otherwise.
• is_dropout: 1 if the founder dropped out of university before starting their company. O if the founder did not drop out of university.
• top_tier_uni: 1 if the founder graduated from a top 50 university, according to the QS World University Rankings, before starting their company. O otherwise.
• multiple_degrees: 1 if the founder received more than one academic degree before starting their company. O otherwise.
• entrepreneurship_education: 1 if the founder studied entrepreneurship or attended an entrepreneurship program (e.g., incubator, accelerator) before starting their company. O otherwise.
• few_years_experience: 1 if the founder had 1-5 years of work experience before starting their company. O otherwise.
• decade_experience: 1 if the founder had 10 or more years of work experience before starting their company. O if the founder had less than 10 years of experience before starting their company.
• big_tech_experience: 1 if the founder worked at a big tech company (NVIDIA, Google, Meta, Apple, Amazon, or Microsoft) before starting their company. 0 otherwise.
• comm_experience: 1 if the founder has experience in marketing, public relations, or a related field before starting their company. O otherwise.
• exec_experience: 1 if the founder held a senior executive role (e.g., CEO, COO, CTO, VP, President) before starting their company. O otherwise.
• is_investor: 1 if the founder worked as an investor (e.g., Venture Capital, Angel Investor) before starting their company. O otherwise.
• is_board_member: 1 if the founder served on a board of directors before starting their company. 0 otherwise.
• international_uni: 1 if the founder attended a university outside the US before starting their company. O otherwise.
• lived_multiple_countries: 1 if the founder lived in multiple countries before starting their company (e.g., studied at universities in multiple countries or worked in different countries before founding their company). 0 otherwise.
• has_job_hopped: 1 if the founder has changed employers frequently (every 1-2 years) before starting their company. O otherwise.
• has_promotions: 1 if the founder received any promotions within a place of work before starting their company (e.g., employment data shows that their role at a certain employer changed over time). O otherwise.

sections.title: Applying boolean flags
sections.content: The boolean flag values for each founder were generated through few-shot prompting and feeding fifty founder summaries to the LLM. Then, success rates were calculated for each possible value (True or False) of the boolean flags. A shortened version of the prompt used for labelling is in the appendix below.

sections.title: 2.3 Predicting success through machine learning
sections.content: After engineering numeric variables about founders' education, entrepreneurial levels, personas, and more, we ran three machine learning models to classify founder success based on these variables: linear regression, random forest, and XGBoost. The models were trained on a set of 240 instances and tested on two separate test sets to reflect different scenarios that a venture capitalist fund might face. The first test set contained 28 unsuccessful and two successful founders, and the second contained 15 of each group. Performance metrics, such as accuracy and precision, were then used to evaluate and compare the effectiveness of the models.

sections.title: 3.1 Level segmentation
sections.content: The total counts and rounded success rates by level are shown in Table 3. The success rates are below 50 percent for Levels 1 to 4 and above 50 percent for the others. This finding makes sense given that founders assigned higher levels have more experience with entrepreneurship. Levels 5, 9, and 10 have 100-percent success rates, though the data on L5 and L10 is extremely limited. The perfect success rate of L9 (founders with previous unicorn startups), however, is still noteworthy.

sections.title: 3.2 Persona segmentation
sections.content: Table 4 summarizes the total counts and success rates by persona. Since each founder can be assigned more than one persona, the total counts sum to a number greater than the sample size. Notably, Persona P (founders with experience in nonprofit organizations) has a zero-percent success rate. Meanwhile, Personas Q (founders who have received notable awards) and R (founders with military service background) have success rates of at least 90 percent, indicating potentially desirable traits in startup founders.

sections.title: 3.3 Additional boolean flags
sections.content: Table 5 shows the total counts and rounded success rates for a subset of the boolean flags. For the sake of brevity, the variables are only displayed if the difference in success rate between True and False values is greater than five percentage points. The greatest differences are seen within is_dropout, is_top_tier_consultant, and is_top_tier_banker, though there is very little data for True values in each of those variables.

sections.title: 3.4 Machine learning models
sections.content:
Table 6 compares performance metrics for the three models tested. As stated above, test set 1 contains 28 unsuccessful and two successful founders, and test set 2 contains 15 of each group.
Accuracy is simply the proportion of correct predictions among an entire test dataset. Precision measures the proportion of true positives among all positive predictions that is, the proportion of startups that a VC supports that become successful. The F1 score aims to assess predictive performance by taking the harmonic mean of accuracy and precision. Finally, TPR indicates the True Positive Rate, equal to $\frac{true\ positives}{true\ positives + false\ negatives}$. In context, this metric is the proportion of founders that a VC fund chooses out of the total pool of successful founders.
In general, based on these metrics, linear regression performs better on the dataset with 28 unsuccessful and two successful founders whereas the other models perform better on the evenly-split dataset. The random forest model also performs better than XGBoost overall.
Among these metrics, precision is likely the most important in the context of venture capital, as one of the main goals of VC funds is to maximize the proportion of successful startups in their portfolio. By this measure, either linear regression or random forest seems to be the best model depending on the makeup of the dataset being used for prediction. When there are few successful founders in the data, linear regression performs best, with a precision of 18.2%. However, given a more evenly split dataset, random forest is very effective, with a precision of 70.6%.

sections.title: 4.1 Conclusions
sections.content: The features engineered for the purpose of predicting startup success meaning being valued at $500M in some way appear very promising. When receiving these features as inputs, all machine learning models explored in this paper perform relatively well, particularly in the context of venture capital and investment. Additionally, the success rates of different founder classifications such as the high success rate of founders with military backgrounds suggest notable relationships between certain founder characteristics and their ability to scale a startup.

sections.title: 4.2 Limitations and future directions
sections.content:
One limitation in the sampling and prediction process is that founders were considered individually, regardless of whether started their company with a co-founder. Predictions about startup success were made assuming that the given individual was the only founder of the company. However, the characteristics of the entire founding team likely contribute to a startup's success, so our models' predictive ability might be more limited for multi-founder companies.
Another limitation is the reliability of large language models. Although some initial LLM outputs were reviewed manually to ensure correctness and adjust the prompts as needed, not all 300 instances in the sample were inspected in this manner. This somewhat limits the confidence in the results. For instance, there may be inaccuracies in the founders' total years of work experience as outputted by the LLM. The model calculated these figures by summing the durations of a founder's previous jobs, but some jobs may overlap, leading to an overestimation of the number of years in the professional world.
An additional finding about this research is that one of the persona categories, (S), pertains to whether a founder is female. This persona was generated in an unsupervised manner without human intervention. We kept this persona in this research to flag potential issues with LLMs while making decisions in an autonomous way. This is especially important as many firms are introducing autonomous AI agents to augment decision making in their investment decision processes.
Future research should address these limitations by considering the interactions between the characteristics of co-founders and further refining the prompting strategies. Future research can also examine the importance of certain features in determining startup success. The success rate analysis in this study and prior studies continue to suggest that there are many hidden features that are related to success than others. Therefore, this research topic should be further pursued.
